page.title: 17The New Town of Edinburgh
page.content: Edinburgh, until the 1760's a crowded huddle of buildings around the Royal Mile, was extended by building a New Town beyond the Nor'Loch.James Craig's Plan was one of the earliest examples of town planning. Its spacious layout and graceful architecture earned Edinburgh the title of 'Athens of the North'.The area was mainly housing for the capital's wealthier citizens.Today it is the headquarters of financial/ legal organisations and the main {shopping}area. Many of the fine Georgian houses are now used as offices, but a large residential community still remains in the New Town. Princes Street is the main shopping axis and one of the city's main{tourist}attractions. Change and redevelopment have occurred, but conservation of the city's{landscape} is now much more actively pursued.
